fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A preabelian category is an additive category which has all kernels and cokernels; hence is finitely complete and cocomplete.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since additive categories have biproducts, it suffices to show that kernels and cokernels give equalizers and coequalizers; the equalizer of f and g is the same as the kernel of f - g, and dually for coequalizers.

fr:title.text: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given that f is a mono, and noting that the zero map z\xrightarrow {0} x equalizes f and x\xrightarrow {0} y, any other map x\to z which equalizes these maps must also be 0. The zero map factors uniquely through the object 0, so that 0 satisfies the universal property of the kernel.
The coimage is now the cokernel of the kernel, hence the cokernel of the zero map 0\to x, hence the coequalizer of the zero map with itself, hence just the identity at x.
Exactness follows from the definition of an exact sequence.
A preabelian category is abelian if every morphism is strict, i.e. if the natural map from its coimage to its image is an isomorphism.

A sequence \dots \xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i + 1}} x_i\xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i}} x_{i - 1}\xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i - 1}} \dots in a preabelian category is exact if \ker \text {d}_{i - 1} \cong \operatorname {im} \text {d}_i for each i. In particular, the sequence is a chain complex; if the category is abelian, this equivalently means its chain homology vanishes.
An additive category is a preadditive category with finite direct sums. (In particular, it has nullary direct sums, hence a zero object.)
The kernel of a map f is the equalizer of f and the zero map, when this data exists. The cokernel is the coequalizer of f and the zero map.
Let C be a category. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: C has a terminal object, binary products, and equalizers;
C has a terminal object and pullbacks.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first immediately implies the next two, because they refer only to the existence of certain finite limits.
The second implies the first by the same construction as the proof of the completeness criterion, noticing there that if the indexing category J is finite, then so are each of the products.
A category is finite if it has only finitely many morphisms.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.
